items.title: A Crisis Deferred
items.excerpt: Early in Harriet Jacobs’s memoir, Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl, Jacobs receives a new pair of shoes from her grandmother in time for a February snowstorm, only for the mistress of the household to make her take them off. The mistress—jealous of her husband’s lecherous…

items.title: A Knock at the Door
items.excerpt: “Hello.” The voice I heard when I picked up the phone on Election Day was low, leaden, and remote, as if spoken from a crypt. “This is Andrew Cuomo.” It was a recorded message urging me to vote. Even as his speech quickened—the city must “move forward ,” he said, with rising e…

items.title: Wave of Domination
items.excerpt: What this weekend’s strikes on Iran clarify is that the post–October 7 period has marked the terminal phase of the liberal international order. For eight decades since the end of World War II, the set of economic, political, diplomatic, and legal arrangements that make up the …
